content: everyone why lock here welcome back a
lot of input lately about why don't you make some chaos base terrain so I had
this one piece in my junk man I've been waiting to use and I thought this would
be a good opportunity I just didn't think much I just went went went get the
project done and I ended up with something that doesn't look anything
like my normal aesthetic which has me pretty excited so without any ado let's
just jump right in and build it a few episodes ago I made jungle scatter
terrain and I used this ball of fake leaf clumps for that project but once
all the fake plants were plucked off this is the structure that was left
underneath so I saved it waiting for inspiration which finally hit so first
it's actually two loosely connected half so I used super glue to join them
together for real you could see a lot of plastic flashing but I'm not going to
take the time to clean that up this is chaos terrain after all it'll look
gnarly or that way and this is a pretty thick necklace chain from the craft
store so outside with all of this and two good coats of primer
krylon and rust-oleum make great mat spray primers for the chains I needed
two base coat them in brown and I had brown primer leftover from my recent
Promethean pipes episode so I use that and hit the chains with it giving it a
few hours to really cure before the next step which is that I took terracotta
just a very desaturated orange and with a splayed out junk brush or a sponge
randomly jab this color all over so it's covering up about half of the brown and
with that dry same technique again but using metallic gunmetal these are just
cheap acrylic craft paints there's a close-up of the result decent looking
but extremely easy rusty chain for the sphere itself I airbrushed with a good
metallic brass Vallejo this was a bit shiny needed something so
I took some brown wash in this case army painter soft tone and slathered it all
over heavy coat don't care about smoothness gave it a couple hours to dry
and then I tried just a quick light dry brush with a metallic silver in a few
spots but I determined it wasn't really giving me the look I wanted so I stopped
and that became the bottom to make the base I used extruded polystyrene or home
insulation you could also use expanded polystyrene which is those blocks of
white popcorn like foam that tend to come in packages anyway i tapered the
edges cut some pieces out dug out the center of the top piece this would
eventually become the blood spring and I hot glued all those chunks together then
onto my new favorite crafting material sculpt a mold or any sort of modeling
paste of your choice so two parts powder to one part water and I just spread it
on there to cover everything up I'm gonna leave that overnight to dry but
meantime I took some more foam and I cut small cubes without any guide
deliberately trying to make them look warped actually and then skewered them
with a toothpick using hot glue to secure everything together then I beat
them up with some balled up aluminum foil to create a rocky texture and round
off the corners a little bit followed by a solid coat of white PVA glue such as
Elmer's to act as both a primer and make that pillar hard and tough the exposed
toothpick gets stuck into the base with some hot glue underneath to secure it
now to create the actual blood falls I could use hot glue but that's gonna take
a lot of hot glue and it's gonna look like a thick flow this is blood it
shouldn't look like lava I could use acrylic resin water kit but this takes
like four days to cure and you can't mix in any paint or dyes because then it
won't cure this is a really cheap product and I don't want to buy a proper
modeling kit and have to wait so I ended up using some smooth cast resin this
stuff cures heart is plastic in ten minutes
Jeremy from Blackmagic craft turned me on to it and I love it it's probably
overkill for this project especially in terms of cost but it will let me move
right along with the project too now so I mixed it up 5050 very thoroughly
solid minute of stirring and then poured now the idea was hopefully the spring
would fill up and then naturally flow down the three waterfalls that I had
carved out of the base at one of them I didn't go as deep as I should have so I
poured directly on it to help things out but by and large this worked as I hoped
it would after ten minutes it was totally cured there's some bubbles in
there I did not expect that but I kind of liked it
bubbling blood is gnarly so this will work let's move on primer the foam
pillars are protected from the spray paint by that coat of white PVA glue
that done more white glue to do some flocking I'm not doing my usual total
coverage of sand instead I applied a full area of glue but then carefully
sprinkled the pebbles and sand in patches and streaks simply because I
want to try a new look something different than I usually do this is low
gauge wire it's thick it's bendable but strong you can find it in a crafting
supply store or harvest it from in-wall electrical wiring from the hardware
store so I pre-drilled a pretty deep hole into
the pillars with a toothpick then injected it with white glue and then
inserted some of that wire while that's drying and setting up I also applied a
solid base coat of burnt umber to the base a slightly watery brush helps the
paint flow nicely into all that sand via capillary action now again trying to do
new things here even as simple as using different colors than I normally do
without thinking I just nabbed two shades of beige dry brushed with the
dark one and then dry brushed with the light one it was okay but still not as
dark and rough as I want my chaos terrain to be so I applied my usual
black wash it's like one part black paint to ten parts water just slather
that all over and after that dried this color is pebble interesting trivia this
very bottle I'm holding was the first bottle of paint that I ever bought after
discovering this hobby six years ago anyway I dry brushed with that and then
with a very light gray a dry brush just the horizontal type slopes
and now on to the main event but first real quick just give me like 25 seconds
to do the obnoxious youtuber influencer thing there are multiple ways to support
the channel if you find the content helpful number one
like subscribe reminder bail number two patreon while ox armory number three
Amazon affiliate links just use the links in the video description below
when you buy stuff totally transparent to you the only difference is I get a
small commission number four heroes hoard for you 3d printers out there are
tons of selection including Altru tiles lines and number five my modules on the
DMS Guild written for D&D 5th edition they're pretty good not great but you
know good so now for the blood this is Vallejo gory red I airbrushed it onto
the blood flows easy took four coats about five minutes of airbrushing but it
got there the pillars I simply base coated with
Bay's using a brush and then washed them with a strong coat of brown looks like I
used army painter strong tone this time
next it was time to figure out the sphere i estimate the height that i
wanted it at hot glued it to that wire and cut off the excess wire this was a
bit flimsy still so i decided to do a second wire from another pillar and that
improved strength considerably again these are just blobs of hot glue to
connect the wires to the sphere now for the chains time to drape them in a most
chaotic way in the top of the foam pillars i got out a small hole filled
that with hot glue and then inserted the first link in the chain it's a very
strong connection easy
so I draped a total of three chains over the sphere cutting away any extra links
so that they all looked taut giving the illusion that the sphere is like trying
to break away but these chains are holding it back few final touches the
blood could be more dynamic so I took a brighter red and airbrushed it down the
center of the flows and this did give it some nice subtle complexity also with a
fine tip brush I went back to that original red and did some rivulets some
random trails going off of the main flow and the top things off a nice happy
little skull what I've set up here is a previously holey world that is obviously
in ruins due to a fissure in the warp having manifested and in this case
that's what the hell's fear is representing legions of demons are
pouring out of this thing now going off in three prongs to raid the ruins of
this city some of you may recognize these models this is sea bass it's army
my next-door neighbor who's been on several battle reports before with this
army if you missed the announcement I moved all my gameplay related content
including battle reports to my new youtube channel why lock plays so you
can check it out there could use it for anything story piece and your D&D
campaign it could be a portal it could be a cage it could be a useable artifact
whatever or maybe you set up a scene where the bad guys trying to like
baptize the heroes in blood and you can literally put the models there on the
blood spring but really the inspiration for this aesthetic is the armies of corn
in Warhammer 40k so blood brass spikes and a predominance of red and black I'll
probably just use it as an obstacle line of sight blocker not occupiable anyway
super fun project entirely conceptualized and then built around one
piece of trash if you like this particular project here's two more you
might want to check out also enjoy this community showcase I'm why alot thanks
for joining and I'll see you next time
